I love that American Gigolo style, it is really good.
As far as I remember, I think that he's wearing full armani in that movie.
Downsides on this style: it can be very expensive, sure you may find some cheap vintage pieces, but rule of thumb we're talking about high quality natural fiber clothes, tailored clothes etc, so mall tier brands probably wont cut it. Also for someone in their early twenties, sometimes this very menswear look can look off, the best analogy is you may end up looking like you're wearing your fathers clothes.

If you're looking for some inspo, I think that brands like husbands paris are a good start, even if you can't afford it they post inspo on ther instagram.
And since we are talking about instagram, there are a million accounts that post vintage menswear magazines scans. A good one is @vintagemenswearmagazines, I bet you'll find something that you like.

Hi anon.

Please, don't try to pursue what is 'trendy' now. Fashion trends are cycling way faster than usual and they're harder to keep up with and be sustainable for longevity of your wardrobe. I think it's all a scam and it will make you more miserable if you're trying to fit in with zoomer crowd. I'm a year older than you, and as much as I like what some young 'trendy' people are wearing these days, I don't really find it endearing or characteristic of any sort of individuality.. To me, dressing ultra 'trendy' just feels vapid and obnoxious, and it seems like a lot of young people have something to prove in the way they present themselves and go too hard with the way they look. In their attempts at looking unique, I find they are all just looking like part of the same crowd.

I think this style is still fairly relevant anyway, and it holds up. It's just classic vintage attire, stuff you can easily pick up at the thrift and make special and unique to your taste. I wouldn't be wearing the checkerboard vans anymore, but try to find some nice, interesting sneakers that are to your taste. imo, shoes are where personality can make its way into your outfit. a personal choice of shoe makes an outfit really stand out to me, as opposed to a 'trendy' shoe that is getting circulated like crazy (see the sambas, new balances, tiger onitsuka's, all fine shoes but predictable and tells me the wearer is only shopping what influencers tell them to).

as >>17386926 said, it's very mac demarco core but i don't think that style has actually aged too much. I still like it, maybe cause I was a sucker for it in high school myself, but there's something kinda comforting about the look, so don't just give it up because you're worried about being out of date. Just try to add some personal touches, your confidence will matter more in the end.

>Old cotton t shirt (one for cleaning, another for applying conditioners)

>Wooden shoe trees ($10-15)

>mud: allow it to dry then brush off
>salt: water and cloth as soon as possible
